hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הוּא בְּחֵלֶב הַמְכַסֶּה אֶת הַקֶּרֶב, וְהֵן בְּחֵלֶב שֶׁעַל הַדַּקִּין, מַהוּ? מִי אָמְרִינַן: אַף עַל גַּב דְּקׇרְבָּנָן שָׁוֶה, כֵּיוָן דְּמִתְּרֵי קְרָאֵי קָאָתוּ, הָא פְּלִיגִין בְּטַעְמַיְיהוּ, אוֹ דִלְמָא שֵׁם חֵלֶב אֶחָד הוּא?
human_translation: But with regard to fat that covers the innards, and with regard to fat that is on the small intestines, what is Do we say: Although their offerings are equal, since it is from two verses come, are distinct in their reasons? Or perhaps, the category of fat is one
llm_translation: Rather, it is in the fat that covers the innards, and they are in the fat that is on the intestines, what? Who said: Even though our sacrifices are equal, since they are derived from two verses, they argue about their reasons, or perhaps it is one type of fat?

hebrew_text: אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר שֵׁם חֵלֶב אֶחָד הוּא, הוּא בְּחֵלֶב וְהֵן בְּדָם, מַהוּ? מִי אָמְרִינַן: בְּטַעְמַיְיהוּ הָא פְּלִיגִין, אוֹ דִלְמָא כֵּיוָן דְּשָׁוִין בְּקׇרְבָּן בָּתַר קׇרְבָּן אָזְלִינַן? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: If you say the category of fat is one with regard to fat and with regard to blood, what is Do we say they are distinct in their reasons, Or perhaps, since fat and blood are equal in offering we follow the offering, shall stand
llm_translation: If you find to say the name "chelev" is one, it is in fat and they are in blood, what? Do we say: they differ in their taste, or perhaps since they are both involved in one offering, we follow the latter offering? This remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: שֶׁאֵין בֵּית דִּין חַיָּיבִין עַד שֶׁיּוֹרוּ לְבַטֵּל מִקְצָת וּלְקַיֵּים מִקְצָת וְכוּ׳. מְנָלַן דְּעַד שֶׁיּוֹרוּ לְבַטֵּל מִקְצָת וּלְקַיֵּים מִקְצָת? כִּדְאָמְרִינַן בְּאִידַּךְ פִּירְקִין: ״וְנֶעֱלַם דָּבָר״ – ״דָּבָר״ – וְלֹא כָּל הַגּוּף.
human_translation: As the court is not liable unless issue a ruling to nullify part and to sustain part From where do we that unless issue a ruling to nullify part and to sustain part as we say in the other chapter “And the matter is hidden” a matter, but not the entire essence
llm_translation: The court is not obligated until they instruct to annul some and to uphold some, etc. Whence do we derive that they are not obligated until they instruct to annul some and to uphold some? As we say in the other chapter: "and a matter is hidden" - "a matter" - and not the entire body.

hebrew_text: וְכֵן הַמָּשִׁיחַ. מְנָלַן? דִּכְתִיב: ״לְאַשְׁמַת הָעָם״, הֲרֵי מָשִׁיחַ כְּצִבּוּר.
human_translation: And likewise the anointed From where do we as it is written: so as to bring guilt upon the people” an anointed is like public.
llm_translation: And so too the Messiah. Whence do we derive this? As it is written: "For the transgression of my people" (Isaiah 53:8), the Messiah is like the congregation.

hebrew_text: וְלֹא בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה כּוּ׳. מְנָלַן? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: לְפִי שֶׁיָּצְאָה עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה לָדוּן בְּעַצְמָהּ, יָכוֹל יְהוּ חַיָּיבִין עַל עֲקִירַת מִצְוָה כּוּלָּהּ?
human_translation: And not with regard to idol worship From where do we as the Sages taught Due to that idol worship left to be discussed by itself might that would be liable for nullifying the mitzva in its entirety.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And not with idol worship, like. Whence? For the Rabbis taught: Since idol worship has gone out to be judged by itself, is it possible that they are liable for uprooting an entire commandment?

hebrew_text: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״מֵעֵינֵי״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״מֵעֵינֵי״. מָה לְהַלָּן בְּבֵית דִּין, אַף כָּאן נָמֵי בְּבֵית דִּין. וּמָה לְהַלָּן ״דָּבָר״ וְלֹא כׇּל הַגּוּף, אַף כָּאן נָמֵי ״דָּבָר״ וְלֹא כׇּל הַגּוּף.
human_translation: “from the eyes of” is stated here, and “from the eyes of” is stated there, Just as there in court, so too here, in court. And just as there, a matter, but not the entire essence, so too here, a matter, but not the entire essence.
llm_translation: It is stated here "from the eyes," and it is stated there "from the eyes." Just as there, in the court, so too here, in the court. And just as there "a matter" and not the entire body, so too here "a matter" and not the entire body.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין חַיָּיבִין אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת הַמַּעֲשֶׂה, וְכֵן הַמָּשִׁיחַ, וְלֹא בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה – אֵין חַיָּיבִין אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת הַמַּעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: The court is liable only for absence of matter, with unwitting of the action And likewise, the anointed And with regard to idol worship only for absence of the matter, with unwitting of the action
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One is only liable for a hidden matter in conjunction with inadvertent action, and so too with the anointed priest, and not with regard to idol worship - one is only liable for a hidden matter in conjunction with inadvertent action.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָלַן? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״יִשְׁגּוּ״ – יָכוֹל יְהוּ חַיָּיבִין עַל שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״יִשְׁגּוּ וְנֶעֱלַם דָּבָר״, אֵין חַיָּיבִין אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: From where do we as the Sages taught shall act unwittingly” might that they will be liable for unwitting of an action. the verse states: “Shall act unwittingly, and the matter was hidden” liable only for absence of matter, with unwitting of an action
llm_translation: Gemara: From where do we derive this? For the Rabbis taught: "They shall be guilty" - Could it be that one is liable for unintentional transgression of a deed? The Torah teaches: "They shall be guilty and the matter is hidden," indicating that one is only liable for hidden matters along with unintentional transgression of a deed.

hebrew_text: וְכֵן הַמָּשִׁיחַ. מְנָלַן? דִּכְתִיב: ״לְאַשְׁמַת הַעָם״, הֲרֵי מָשִׁיחַ כְּצִבּוּר.
human_translation: And likewise the anointed From where do we as it is written so as to bring guilt upon the people” an anointed is like public.
llm_translation: And so too the Messiah. Whence do we derive this? As it is written: "For the transgression of my people" (Isaiah 53:8), the Messiah is like the congregation.

hebrew_text: וְלֹא בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה. מְנָלַן?
human_translation: And with regard to idol worship only for absence of matter, with unwitting of an action From where do we
llm_translation: And not in foreign worship, rather on inadvertent transgression of a matter with negligence of action. Whence?

hebrew_text: דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: לְפִי שֶׁיָּצְאָה עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה לָדוּן בְּעַצְמָהּ, יָכוֹל יְהוּ חַיָּיבִין עַל שִׁגְגַת הַמַּעֲשֶׂה? נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״מֵעֵינֵי״ וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״מֵעֵינֵי״, מָה לְהַלָּן אֵין חַיָּיבִין אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה, אַף כָּאן אֵין חַיָּיבִין אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: as the Sages taught: Due to that idol worship left to be discussed by itself might that would be liable for unwitting the action. “from the eyes of” is stated here, and “from the eyes of” is stated there, Just as there they are liable only for absence of matter, with unwitting of an action so too here, they are liable only for absence of matter, with unwitting of an action
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: Since a foreign service has emerged to be judged on its own, can they possibly be liable for an unwitting transgression of the act? It is stated here "from the eyes" and it is stated elsewhere "from the eyes," just as there they are only liable for concealing a matter with an unwitting transgression of the act, so too here they are only liable for concealing a matter with an unwitting transgression of the act.

hebrew_text: וְאִילּוּ מָשִׁיחַ בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה לָא קָתָנֵי, מַתְנִיתִין מַנִּי? רַבִּי הִיא.
human_translation: Whereas, an anointed with regard to idol worship is not taught Whose the mishna? It is Rabbi
llm_translation: And if the Messiah is involved in foreign worship, it is not taught, where is this Mishnah from? It is from Rabbi Hiya.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: מָשִׁיחַ בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה – רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בְּהֶעְלֵם דָּבָר. וְשָׁוִין שֶׁבִּשְׂעִירָה, וְשָׁוִין שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא אָשָׁם תָּלוּי.
human_translation: as it is taught an anointed in idol worship, Rabbi says: for unwitting of an action, And the Rabbis say: for absence of matter, And they agree that with a female goat and they agree that he does not bring a provisional guilt-offering.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: The anointed High Priest in a case of foreign worship - Rabbi says: through unintentional action. And the Sages say: through concealing a matter. And they are equal in the case of the he-goat, and they are equal in the case of not bringing a guilt-offering.

hebrew_text: וְתִסְבְּרַאּ: בִּזְדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וּבְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת מִי קָתָנֵי?
human_translation: And you understand In whose intentional excision from the World-to-Come [ karet ] and whose unwitting a sin-offering, does it teach
llm_translation: And it was thought: for intentional sin, excision, and for unintentional sin, a sin offering, who is the Tanna?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא תָּנֵי הָא הוּא הַדִּין לְהָא. הָכָא נָמֵי תְּנָא הָא וְהוּא הַדִּין לְהָא.
human_translation: Rather, teaches this the same is true with regard to that Here too, taught this and the same is true with regard to that
llm_translation: Rather, it was taught: this is the same as that. Here it was taught by one Tanna, and there it was taught by another Tanna.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי? אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְכִפֶּר הַכֹּהֵן עַל הַנֶּפֶשׁ הַשֹּׁגֶגֶת בְּחֶטְאָה בִשְׁגָגָה״. ״הַנֶּפֶשׁ״ – זֶה מָשִׁיחַ, ״הַשֹּׁגֶגֶת״ – זֶה נָשִׂיא, ״בְּחֶטְאָה בִּשְׁגָגָה״ – רַבִּי סָבַר: חֵטְא זֶה בִּשְׁגָגָה יְהֵא.
human_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi the verse states “And the priest shall atone for the soul that acted unwittingly, when he sins unwittingly” “the soul,” that is an anointed “that acted unwittingly,” that is a king; “when he sins unwittingly,” Rabbi holds this sin shall be unwittingly,
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi's opinion? The verse says: "And the priest shall make atonement for the soul that sins through error by mistake." "The soul" - this refers to the anointed one (Messiah), "that sins through error by mistake" - Rabbi holds: the sin referred to here should be unintentional.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: מִי שֶׁחַטָּאתוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה, יָצָא מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁאֵין חַטָּאתוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה אֶלָּא בְּהֶעְלֵם דָּבָר.
human_translation: And the Rabbis hold: one whose sin-offering for an unwitting exclude an anointed whose a sin-offering for an unwitting only for absence of matter, together
llm_translation: The sages say: One whose sin was unintentional, the Messiah has come for him, for his sin was not intentional but due to a hidden matter.

hebrew_text: וְשָׁוִין שֶׁבִּשְׂעִירָה כְּיָחִיד. מְנָלַן? דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאִם נֶפֶשׁ אַחַת״ – אֶחָד יָחִיד וְאֶחָד נָשִׂיא וְאֶחָד מָשִׁיחַ – כּוּלָּם בִּכְלַל ״נֶפֶשׁ אַחַת״ הֵן.
human_translation: And they agree that with a female goat as individual. From where do we as the verse states: “And if one soul individual, a king, and an anointed they are all in the category of “one soul.”
llm_translation: And equal in the he-goat as an individual. From where do we derive this? As the verse states: "And if one soul" - one individual, one leader, and one anointed one - all of them are included in the term "one soul."

hebrew_text: וְשָׁוִין שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא אָשָׁם תָּלוּי. מְנָלַן? דִּכְתִיב: ״וְכִפֶּר [עָלָיו] הַכֹּהֵן עַל שִׁגְגָתוֹ אֲשֶׁר שָׁגָג״. רַבִּי סָבַר: מִי שֶׁכׇּל חֶטְאוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה, יָצָא זֶה שֶׁאֵין [כׇּל] חֶטְאוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה, אֶלָּא בְּהֶעְלֵם דָּבָר.
human_translation: And they agree that he does not bring a provisional guilt-offering. From where do we as it is written “And the priest shall atone for him for his unwitting act that he performed unwittingly” Rabbi holds: one whose sin-offering all for an unwitting exclude that as all of his sin-offerings are not for an unwitting rather, of absence of matter,
llm_translation: And similar cases that do not bring a guilt offering. From where do we derive this? As it is written: "And the priest shall make atonement for him concerning the error that he erred." Rabbi holds: One whose entire sin is unintentional, this one has fulfilled his obligation, but not one whose entire sin is intentional, only in concealing a matter.

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי ״כׇּל״ כְּתִיב? אִין דְּאִם כֵּן נִכְתּוֹב ״עַל שִׁגְגָתוֹ״. לְמָה לִי ״אֲשֶׁר שָׁגָג״ הָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּעַד דְּאִיכָּא כׇּל חֶטְאוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה. יָצָא מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁאֵין כׇּל חֶטְאוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה אֶלָּא בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, וְלֹא בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת אֶלָּא בְּהֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: Is it written all Yes, As if so let write “For his unwitting act.” Why do I “That he performed unwittingly”? This teaches us that unless all his sin-offerings is for unwitting exclude an anointed all of whose a sin-offering for an unwitting is only in idol worship, but in the rest of mitzvot only for absence of matter, with unwitting of an action
llm_translation: From the hand of "all" it is written? No, for if so it were written "by his unintentional error." Why do I need "that he erred"? This teaches us that as long as there is "all," his entire sin is unintentional. The Messiah will come only for sins committed unintentionally in idolatry, and not for other commandments, but for concealing a matter with unintentional action.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן: מִי שֶׁחֶטְאוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה, יָצָא מָשִׁיחַ, שֶׁאֵין חֶטְאוֹ בִּשְׁגָגָה לֹא בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וְלֹא בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת, אֶלָּא בְּהֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: And the Rabbis one whose sin-offerings is for an unwitting exclude an anointed whose a sin-offering is not for an unwitting neither in idol worship, nor in the rest of mitzvot, rather for absence of matter, with unwitting of an action
llm_translation: The sages said: One who sinned inadvertently, the anointed one has come forth, for his sin was inadvertent, not in idol worship nor in other commandments, but in concealing a matter with inadvertent action.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין בֵּית דִּין חַיָּיבִין עַד שֶׁיּוֹרוּ בְּדָבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת, וְכֵן הַמָּשִׁיחַ, וְלֹא בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה – עַד שֶׁיּוֹרוּ עַל דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת.
human_translation: The court is not liable unless they issue a ruling with regard to a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering. And likewise the anointed priest Neither for idol worship unless issue a ruling with regard to a matter whose intentional karet , and whose unwitting a sin-offering.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A court is not liable until they deliberate on a matter where intentional transgression incurs karet and unintentional transgression incurs a sin offering, as well as the anointed High Priest. And not in matters of idolatry – until they deliberate on a matter where intentional transgression incurs karet and unintentional transgression incurs a sin offering.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מִנָּלַן?
human_translation: From where do we
llm_translation: From where do we derive this?

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״עָלֶיהָ״ וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״עָלֶיהָ״. מָה לְהַלָּן – דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת, אַף כָּאן – דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת.
human_translation: as it is taught Rabbi says: “that” is stated here and “that” is stated there Just as there a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering, so too here, a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi says: It is stated here "upon it" and it is stated there "upon it." Just as there, it refers to a matter where intentional violation results in excision and unintentional violation results in a sin-offering, so too here, it refers to a matter where intentional violation results in excision and unintentional violation results in a sin-offering.

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן צִבּוּר, מָשִׁיחַ מְנָלַן? ״לְאַשְׁמַת הַעָם״, הֲרֵי מָשִׁיחַ כְּצִבּוּר.
human_translation: We found public From where do we an anointed so as to bring guilt upon the people” an anointed is like public.
llm_translation: We find the congregation, where is the Messiah from? "For the sake of the people," behold the Messiah is like the congregation.

hebrew_text: נָשִׂיא? יָלֵיף ״מִצְוֹת״ ״מִצְוֹת״, כְּתִיב גַּבֵּי נָשִׂיא: ״וְעָשָׂה אַחַת מִכׇּל מִצְוֹת ה׳״, וּכְתִיב בְּצִבּוּר: ״וְעָשׂוּ אַחַת מִכׇּל מִצְוֹת״ – מָה צִבּוּר – דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת, אַף נָשִׂיא – דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת.
human_translation: king? derives “commandments” “commandments” It is written with regard to a king: “And he performed one of all the commandments of the Lord and it is written with regard to public: “And performed one of all the commandments Just as public a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering, so too, a king a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering.
llm_translation: Prince? He should bring a "mitzvah" "mitzvah," it is written regarding a prince: "And he shall do one of all the commandments of the Lord," and it is written regarding the community: "And they shall do one of all the commandments" - just as the community - something whose intentional violation entails excision and unintentional violation entails a sin offering, so too a prince - something whose intentional violation entails excision and unintentional violation entails a sin offering.

hebrew_text: יָחִיד? אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאִם נֶפֶשׁ״, וְיִלְמַד תַּחְתּוֹן מֵעֶלְיוֹן.
human_translation: an individual The verse states: “And if one soul one shall derive lower from upper
llm_translation: Individual? The verse says: "And if a soul," and we learn the lower from the higher.

hebrew_text: וְלֹא בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה עַד שֶׁיּוֹרוּ. בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה מְנָלַן? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: לְפִי שֶׁיָּצְאָה עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה לָדוּן בְּעַצְמָהּ, יָכוֹל יְהוּ חַיָּיבִין אֲפִילּוּ עַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין זְדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת?
human_translation: Neither for idol worship unless issue a ruling In idol worship, from where do we as the Sages taught: Due to that idol worship left to be discussed by itself might that would be liable even not a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And not in foreign worship until they teach. In foreign worship, from where do we derive? For the Rabbis taught: Since foreign worship has emerged to be judged by itself, it is possible that they are liable even for something that its intentional act is not punishable by excision, and its unintentional act is a sin offering.

hebrew_text: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״מֵעֵינֵי״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״מֵעֵינֵי״. מָה לְהַלָּן דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת, אַף כָּאן דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת.
human_translation: “from the eyes of” is stated here, and “from the eyes of” is stated there, Just as there a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering, so too here, a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering.
llm_translation: It is stated here "from the eyes," and it is stated there "from the eyes." Just as there, a matter whose intentional violation results in excision and unintentional violation results in a sin-offering, so too here, a matter whose intentional violation results in excision and unintentional violation results in a sin-offering.

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן צִבּוּר. יָחִיד, נָשִׂיא, מָשִׁיחַ מְנָלַן? אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאִם נֶפֶשׁ אַחַת״, אֶחָד יָחִיד וְאֶחָד נָשִׂיא וְאֶחָד מָשִׁיחַ כּוּלָּן בִּכְלַל ״נֶפֶשׁ אַחַת״ הֵן, וְיִלְמַד תַּחְתּוֹן מִן הָעֶלְיוֹן.
human_translation: We found public from where do we an individual, a king, an anointed the verse states: “And if one soul an individual, a king, and an anointed they all are included in the category of “one soul.” And one shall derive lower from upper
llm_translation: We find a congregation. Individual, leader, Messiah, from where do we derive them? The verse says: "And if one soul," one individual and one leader and one Messiah, all of them included in "one soul," and learn the lower from the higher.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּמַפֵּיק לַהּ לְ״עָלֶיהָ״ לִגְזֵרָה שָׁוָה, כְּדַאֲמַרַן. אֶלָּא לְרַבָּנַן דְּמַפְּקִי לַהּ לְ״עָלֶיהָ״ לַעֲרָיוֹת וְצָרוֹת, דָּבָר שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְשִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת – מְנָא לְהוּ?
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who derives “that” for a verbal analogy in accordance with which we stated. But according to the Rabbis, who derive “that” to those with whom relations are forbidden and rival wives from where do they a matter whose intentional karet and whose unwitting a sin-offering
llm_translation: He left it for the one who brings it up to her "on her" for a similar decree, as we said. Rather, for the Rabbis who bring it up to her "on her" for matters of forbidden relationships and menstrual impurity, a matter whose intentional violation is punishable by excision and unintentional violation is punishable by a sin offering - from where do they derive this?

hebrew_text: נָפְקָא לְהוּ מִדְּמַתְנֵי לֵיהּ רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי לִבְרֵיהּ: ״תּוֹרָה אַחַת יִהְיֶה לָכֶם לָעֹשֶׂה בִּשְׁגָגָה וְהַנֶּפֶשׁ אֲשֶׁר תַּעֲשֶׂה בְּיָד רָמָה וְגוֹ׳״ – הוּקְּשָׁה כׇּל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ לַעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה. מָה עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְעַל שִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת, אַף כָּאן שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת וְעַל שִׁגְגָתוֹ חַטָּאת.
human_translation: They derive it from which Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi taught to his son “There shall be one Torah for you for the one who acts unwittingly. And the soul that performs with an upraised hand, The entire Torah is juxtaposed to idol worship: Just as idol worship which one is liable for its intentional karet and for its unwitting a sin-offering, so too here, one is liable for its intentional karet and for its unwitting a sin-offering.
llm_translation: He went out from the study hall, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said to his son: "There shall be one Torah for you, for one who does something wrong unintentionally, and the soul that does something wrong with a high hand, etc." - The entire Torah was difficult to understand for the laws of foreign worship. Just as foreign worship idolatry for which one is liable for intentional violation is punished with karet spiritual excision, and for unintentional violation with a sin offering, so too here regarding the laws of foreign worship one is liable for intentional violation with karet and for unintentional violation with a sin offering.

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן יָחִיד, נָשִׂיא, וּמָשִׁיחַ, בֵּין בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה בֵּין בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת. צִבּוּר מְנָלַן? יָלֵיף עֶלְיוֹן מִתַּחְתּוֹן.
human_translation: We found an individual, a king, and an anointed priest, both with regard to idol worship and with regard to the rest of the mitzvot, from where do we public One derives upper from lower
llm_translation: I have found an individual, a leader, and a messiah, whether in idolatry or in other commandments. Where does the community derive from them? The higher one is inferred from the lower one.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי, הָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? מַפֵּיק לֵיהּ, לְכִדְתַנְיָא: לְפִי שֶׁמָּצִינוּ שֶׁחִלֵּק הַכָּתוּב בֵּין רַבִּים לִיחִידִים – רַבִּים בְּסַיִיף וּמָמוֹנָן אָבֵד, יְחִידִים בִּסְקִילָה וּמָמוֹנָן פָּלֵט, יָכוֹל נַחְלוֹק בְּקׇרְבְּנוֹתֵיהֶם? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״תּוֹרָה אַחַת יִהְיֶה וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And Rabbi what does he do with this which Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi He derives to that which is taught Due to that we found that the verse distinguished between many, and individuals, many through a sword and their property is lost, individuals through stoning and their property is spared, might that we would distinguish between offerings they the verse states: “There shall be one Torah for you
llm_translation: Rabbi, what does Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi do? He brings out for him, as it was taught: Since we found that the Scripture distinguishes between the many and the individual - the many with the sword and their money is lost, the individuals with stoning and their money is saved, can they divide their sacrifices? The Torah states: "There shall be one Torah."

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב חִלְקִיָּה מֵהַגְרוֹנְיָא: טַעְמָא דְּלֹא חָלַק הַכָּתוּב. הָא חָלַק, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא נַחְלוֹק. מַאי נַיְיתֵי?
human_translation: Rav Ḥilkiya of Hagronya objects to it: The reason that the verse did not distinguish But had the verse distinguished I would say: Let us distinguish What shall they bring?
llm_translation: Challenged him Rav Chilkiyah from Hagronya: The reason that the Scripture did not divide. If it had divided, I would have said it was divided. What is the answer?

hebrew_text: נַיְיתֵי פַּר, צִבּוּר בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת הוּא דְּמַיְיתוּ! נַיְיתֵי פַּר לְעוֹלָה וְשָׂעִיר לְחַטָּאת, צִבּוּר בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה הוּא דְּמַיְיתוּ! נַיְיתֵי שְׂעִיר, נָשִׂיא בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת הוּא דְּמַיְיתֵי! נַיְיתֵי שְׂעִירָה, יָחִיד נָמֵי הַיְינוּ קׇרְבָּנוֹ!
human_translation: Let them bring a bull, it is for the rest of the mitzvot that public brings Let them bring a bull for a burnt-offering and a goat for a sin-offering, it is for idol worship that public brings Let them bring a goat, it is for the rest of the mitzvot that a king brings Let them bring a female goat, that is the offering for an individual, too.
llm_translation: The bull is brought, it is equivalent to the community in other commandments! The bull is brought for a burnt offering and the goat for a sin offering, it is equivalent to idol worship! The he-goat is brought, it is equivalent to a leader in other commandments! The she-goat is brought, only an individual, that is his sacrifice!

hebrew_text: אַלְּמָה לָא אִיצְטְרִיךְ? סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: צִבּוּר מַיְיתֵי פַּר לְעוֹלָה וְשָׂעִיר לְחַטָּאת, הָנֵי נַיְיתֵי אִיפְּכָא – פַּר לְחַטָּאת וְשָׂעִיר לְעוֹלָה. אִי נָמֵי: צָרִיךְ וְאֵין לוֹ תַּקָּנָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Why not necessary? enter your mind to say: public brings a bull for a burnt-offering and a goat for a sin-offering, but this shall bring the opposite: A bull for a sin-offering and a goat for a burnt-offering. Alternatively, must but it has no remedy, teaches us
llm_translation: Why is it not necessary? I would say: The community brings a bull for a burnt offering and a goat for a sin offering, these bring the opposite - a bull for a sin offering and a goat for a burnt offering. If you say: It is necessary but he has no means, it is implied to us.

hebrew_text: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא מִיהַת כִּי כְּתִיבִי הָנֵי קְרָאֵי – בַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה הוּא דִּכְתִיבִי, מַאי מַשְׁמַע? אָמַר רָבָא, וְאִי תֵּימָא רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ כְּדִי. אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְכִי תִשְׁגּוּ וְלֹא תַעֲשׂוּ אֵת כׇּל הַמִּצְוֹת הָאֵלֶּה״, אֵיזוֹ הִיא מִצְוָה שֶׁהִיא שְׁקוּלָה כְּכׇל הַמִּצְוֹת? הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: זוֹ עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה.
human_translation: In any event, everyone agrees where these verses are written, it is with regard to idol worship that they are written. from where inferred? Rava said, and some say Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi and some say unattributed, the verse states: “And when you act unwittingly, and do not perform all these commandments [ kol hamitzvot ] Which is mitzva that is the equivalent of all the mitzvot? You must say: It is idol worship.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: "Dekhulei olma miyehat ki k'tivi hanei k'raei – ba'avodah zarah hu dikhtivi, mai mashma? Amar Rava, ve'imi tema Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, ve'amri la k'dei. Amar kra: 'Ve'khi tishgu v'lo ta'asu et kol hamitzvot ha'eleh,' eizo hi mitzvah shehi sh'kula k'kol hamitzvot? Hevei omer: zo avodah zarah."

hebrew_text: דְּבֵי רַבִּי תָּנָא, אָמַר קְרָא: ״אֲשֶׁר דִּבֶּר ה׳ אֶל מֹשֶׁה״, וּכְתִיב: ״אֲשֶׁר צִוָּה ה׳ אֲלֵיכֶם בְּיַד מֹשֶׁה״, אֵיזוֹ הִיא מִצְוָה שֶׁהִיא בְּדִיבּוּרוֹ שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא וְצִוָּה עַל יְדֵי מֹשֶׁה? הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: זוֹ עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה. דְּתָנָא רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״אָנֹכִי״ וְ״לֹא יִהְיֶה לְךָ״ מִפִּי הַגְּבוּרָה שְׁמַעְנוּם.
human_translation: The school of Rabbi taught the verse states: “That the Lord spoke to Moses” and it is written: “That the Lord has commanded you by the hand of Moses” Which is mitzva that in the speech the Holy One, Blessed be He, and He commanded by means of Moses? You must say: This is idol worship, as Rabbi Yishmael taught “I and: “You shall have no We, heard them from the mouth of the Almighty.
llm_translation: The House of Rabbi taught, the verse says: "Which the Lord spoke to Moses," and it is written: "Which the Lord commanded you by the hand of Moses." What is the commandment that is in the speech of the Holy One, blessed be He, and was commanded through the hand of Moses? One should say: This is idol worship. As Rabbi Ishmael taught: "I" and "You shall have no other gods" we heard from the mouth of the Almighty.

hebrew_text: דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל תָּנָא:
human_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught
llm_translation: The House of Rabbi Yishmael taught:

hebrew_text: ״לְמִן הַיּוֹם אֲשֶׁר צִוָּה ה׳ וָהָלְאָה לְדוֹרוֹתֵיכֶם״, אֵיזוֹ הִיא מִצְוָה שֶׁהִיא נֶאֶמְרָה בִּתְחִלָּה? הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: זוֹ עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה. וְהָא אָמַר מָר: עֶשֶׂר מִצְוֹת נִצְטַוּוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּמָרָה (דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ תִּשְׁמַע לְקוֹל ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״)? אֶלָּא מְחַוַּורְתָּא כִדְשַׁנִּינַן מֵעִיקָּרָא.
human_translation: from the day that the Lord commanded and onward throughout your generations” Which is mitzva that was stated at the beginning You must say: This is idol worship, But didn’t the Master say: The Jewish people were commanded ten mitzvot in Marah as it is written: “If you shall hearken to the voice of the Lord your God… Rather, it is clear as we initially answered.
llm_translation: "From the day that Hashem commanded and onward to your generations," which commandment was initially stated? One should say: this is idol worship. But didn't Mar say: Israel was commanded with ten commandments at Marah (as it is written: "And it shall be, if you diligently obey the voice of Hashem your God")? Rather, it is a difficulty as we learn from the outset.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין חַיָּיבִין עַל עֲשֵׂה וְעַל לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁבַּמִּקְדָּשׁ, וְאֵין מְבִיאִין אָשָׁם תָּלוּי עַל עֲשֵׂה וְעַל לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁבַּמִּקְדָּשׁ.
human_translation: not liable to a positive or a prohibition related to the Temple And one does not bring a provisional guilt-offering for a positive or a prohibition related to the Temple
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One is not liable for a positive commandment or a negative commandment in the Temple, and one does not bring a guilt offering dependent on a positive commandment or a negative commandment in the Temple.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל חַיָּיבִין עַל עֲשֵׂה וְעַל לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁבַּנִּדָּה, וּמְבִיאִים אָשָׁם תָּלוּי עַל עֲשֵׂה וְעַל לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁבַּנִּדָּה. אֵיזוֹ הִיא מִצְוַת עֲשֵׂה שֶׁבַּנִּדָּה? פְּרוֹשׁ מִן הַנִּדָּה. וּמִצְוַת לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה? אַל תָּבֹא עַל הַנִּדָּה.
human_translation: But is liable for a positive or a prohibition that is related to a menstruating woman, and one brings a provisional guilt-offering for a positive or a prohibition that is related to a menstruating woman. What is positive mitzva that is related to a menstruating woman? Distance from the menstruating woman. And what is the prohibition? Do not engage in intercourse with a menstruating woman.
llm_translation: However, they are liable for positive commandments and negative commandments in the case of a menstruating woman, and they bring a guilt offering dependent on positive commandments and negative commandments in the case of a menstruating woman. What is the positive commandment in the case of a menstruating woman? To separate from the menstruating woman. And what is the negative commandment? Do not approach the menstruating woman.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי דְּצִבּוּר לָא מְחַיְּיבִי קׇרְבָּן בְּעָלְמָא, וְיָחִיד אָשָׁם תָּלוּי נָמֵי לָא?
human_translation: From where are these matters that public is not liable offering at all and an individual too not a provisional guilt-offering
llm_translation: "G'ma mena hanei millei d'tzibbur la mechayevi korban be'alma, ve'yachid asham talui namei la?" Translation: "How do we know that these matters of the community do not obligate a sacrifice in general, and an individual's guilt offering does not depend on them?"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר אַבְדִּימִי: נֶאֱמַר ״וְאָשֵׁם״ בְּחַטָּאת וּבְאָשָׁם תָּלוּי, וְנֶאֱמַר ״וְאָשֵׁמוּ״ בְּצִבּוּר. מָה ״וְאָשֵׁם״ בְּיָחִיד – בְּחַטָּאת קְבוּעָה, אַף ״וְאָשֵׁמוּ״ בְּצִבּוּר – בְּחַטָּאת קְבוּעָה,
human_translation: Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi says: “and he is guilty” is stated with regard to a sin-offering and with regard to a provisional guilt-offering and “And they are guilty” is stated with regard to public. Just as “and he is guilty” with regard to an individual concerning a fixed sin-offering, so too, “and they are guilty” with regard to public concerning a fixed sin-offering.
llm_translation: Rav Yitzchak bar Avdimi said: It is stated "and guilt" in regards to a sin offering and a guilt offering is dependent, and it is stated "and they shall be guilty" in regards to a communal offering. Just as "and guilt" in the case of an individual is a fixed sin offering, so too "and they shall be guilty" in the case of a communal offering is a fixed sin offering.

hebrew_text: וּמָה צִבּוּר בְּחַטָּאת קְבוּעָה, אַף אָשָׁם תָּלוּי נָמֵי אֵין בָּא אֶלָּא עַל סְפֵק חַטָּאת קְבוּעָה. אָמְרִי: אִי הָכִי, קׇרְבָּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד נָמֵי, הָא כְּתִיב: ״וְהָיָה כִּי יֶאְשַׁם לְאַחַת מֵאֵלֶּה״! דָּנִין (״אָשֵׁם״ מִן ״אָשֵׁמוּ״) [״אָשֵׁמוּ״ מִן ״אָשֵׁם״], וְאֵין דָּנִין ״אָשֵׁם״ מִן ״יֶאְשַׁם״.
human_translation: And just as with regard to public a fixed sin-offering, so too, a provisional guilt-offering comes only for uncertainty a fixed sin-offering. say: If so, isn’t it also written a sliding-scale offering: “And it shall be when he shall be guilty of one of these matters” One derives “they are guilty” from “he is guilty,” but one does not derive “he is guilty” from “he shall be guilty,”
llm_translation: And what is the congregation in a fixed sin-offering, so too a guilt-offering dependent comes before it only for a doubt of a fixed sin-offering. They said: If so, a burnt-offering and a descending offering dependent, as it is written: "And it shall be when he is guilty in one of these"! We judge ("guilt" from "they shall be guilty") "they shall be guilty" from "guilt", and we do not judge "guilt" from "he is guilty".

hebrew_text: וּמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? וְהָא תָּנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״וְשָׁב הַכֹּהֵן״ וּבָא הַכֹּהֵן״ – זוֹ הִיא שִׁיבָה, זוֹ הִיא בִּיאָה! וְעוֹד: נֵילַף מִן ״וְאָשֵׁם״ מִטּוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהוּא טָמֵא וְאָשֵׁם״!
human_translation: And what difference But didn’t the school of Rabbi Yishmael teach “And the priest shall return [ veshav ]” “And the priest shall come [ uva ] This returning this coming And furthermore, let us derive from “and he is guilty,” with regard to the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial as it is written: “And he is ritually impure and he is guilty”
llm_translation: "What is derived from it? And it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: 'And the priest shall return' and 'the priest shall come' - this is returning, this is coming! And furthermore: we learn from 'and he shall be guilty' regarding impurity of the sanctuary and its holiness, as it is written: 'And he is impure and guilty'!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: דָּנִין ״וְאָשֵׁם״ וּ״מִצְוֹת ה׳״ מִן ״וְאָשֵׁם״ וּ״מִצְוֹת ה׳״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב שִׁימִי בַּר אָשֵׁי לְרַב פָּפָּא: וְנֵילַף ״וְאָשֵׁם״ וּנְשִׂיאַת עָוֹן מִן ״וְאָשֵׁם״ וּנְשִׂיאַת עָוֹן!
human_translation: Rav Pappa says: One derives “And he is guilty,” and: “The commandments of the Lord” from “And they are guilty,” and: “The commandments of the Lord” Rav Shimi bar Ashi said to Rav Pappa: Let us derive “And he is guilty and bearing of iniquity” from “And he is guilty and bearing of iniquity”
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: We derive "guilt offering" and "commandments of Hashem" from "guilt offering" and "commandments of Hashem." Rav Shimi bar Ashi said to Rav Papa: Let us derive "guilt offering" and bearing of iniquity from "guilt offering" and bearing of iniquity!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: דָּנִין ״וְאָשֵׁם״ וּ״מִצְוֹת ה׳ אֲשֶׁר לֹא תֵעָשֶׂינָה״ – מִ״וְאָשֵׁם וּמִצְוֹת ה׳ אֲשֶׁר לֹא תֵעָשֶׂינָה״. וְאַל יוֹכִיחַ שְׁמִיעַת קוֹל וּבִיטּוּי שְׂפָתַיִם וְטוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו, שֶׁלֹּא נֶאֱמַר בָּהֶם ״וְאָשֵׁם״ וּ״מִצְוֹת ה׳ אֲשֶׁר לֹא תֵעָשֶׂינָה״.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: One derives “and he is guilty” and “the commandments of the Lord that shall not be done” from “And he is guilty,” and: “The commandments of the Lord that shall not be done” And hear-ing of a voice, and a statement of the lips, and the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial shall not prove as it is not stated concerning them: And he is guilty, and: The commandments of the Lord that shall not be done.
llm_translation: Rather, said Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: We judge "guilt" and "commandments of the Lord that shall not be done" - from "guilt" and "commandments of the Lord that shall not be done." And one may not prove cases through the testimony of a voice, lip movement, impurity of the sanctuary, and his holy things, for it is not stated regarding them "guilt" and "commandments of the Lord that shall not be done."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין חַיָּיבִין עַל שְׁמִיעַת קוֹל, וְעַל בִּיטּוּי שְׂפָתַיִם, וְעַל טוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו. וְהַנָּשִׂיא כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּהֶם, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: הַנָּשִׂיא חַיָּיב בְּכוּלָּן חוּץ מִשְּׁמִיעַת הַקּוֹל, שֶׁהַמֶּלֶךְ לֹא דָּן וְלֹא דָּנִין אוֹתוֹ [לֹא מֵעִיד וְלֹא מְעִידִין אוֹתוֹ].
human_translation: is not liable for hearing of a voice, or for an utterance of the lips, or for the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial And the king is like the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says: The king is liable in all of except for hearing of a voice, as the king neither judges nor judge him; he does not testify nor testify against him.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One is not liable for hearing a voice, for lip movement, or for impurity of the Temple and its sanctities. And the prince is like them, the words of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean. Rabbi Akiva says: The prince is liable for all of them except for hearing a voice, for the king does not judge and is not judged does not testify and is not testified about.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר עוּלָּא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי? אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְהָיָה כִי יֶאְשַׁם לְאַחַת מֵאֵלֶּה״, כֹּל שֶׁמִּתְחַיֵּיב בְּאַחַת – מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּכוּלָּן, וְשֶׁאֵין מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּאַחַת – אֵין מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּכוּלָּן.
human_translation: Ulla said: What is the reason of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? the verse states “And it shall be when he shall be guilty of one of these matters” anyone who becomes liable in one becomes liable in all of and anyone who does not become liable in one does not become liable in any of
llm_translation: Gemara said Ulla: What is the reason of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean? He said a verse: "And when he shall be guilty in one of these," anyone who is liable in one - is liable in all of them, and anyone who is not liable in one - is not liable in all of them.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּאַחַת מֵהֶן, וְאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּכוּלָּן!
human_translation: And say Anyone who becomes liable in one of these and even though he does not become liable in all of them.
llm_translation: And why not: obligated in one of them, even though not obligated in all of them!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי מֵהָכָא, דְּתַנְיָא, הָיָה רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה אוֹמֵר: נֶאֱמַר
human_translation: Rather, the reason of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili is from here, as it is taught Rabbi Yirmeya would say: It is stated:
llm_translation: Rather, the reason for Rabbi Yosei the Galilean is derived from here, as it was taught: Rabbi Yirmeya would say: It is stated,

hebrew_text: ״לֹא תַגִּיעַ יָדוֹ״, וְנֶאֱמַר ״לֹא תַשִּׂיג יָדוֹ״ – מִי שֶׁבָּא לִידֵי עֲנִיּוּת וַעֲשִׁירוּת. יָצָא נָשִׂיא וּמָשִׁיחַ, שֶׁאֵין בָּאִין לִידֵי עֲנִיּוּת,
human_translation: “And if his means suffice not” and it is stated: “And if his means not suffice” one who can come to poverty and wealth. exclude a king and an anointed who cannot come to poverty.
llm_translation: "His hand shall not reach," and it is stated "His hand shall not overtake" - one who comes to poverty and wealth. A prince and Messiah have come out, who do not come to poverty.

hebrew_text: נָשִׂיא – דִּכְתִיב: ״וְעָשָׂה אַחַת מִכׇּל מִצְוֹת ה׳ אֱלֹהָיו״. מִי שֶׁאֵין עַל גַּבָּיו אֶלָּא ה׳ אֱלֹהָיו. מָשִׁיחַ – דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהַכֹּהֵן הַגָּדוֹל מֵאֶחָיו״, שֶׁהוּא גָּדוֹל מֵאֶחָיו בְּנוֹי, בְּכֹחַ, בְּחָכְמָה וּבְעוֹשֶׁר. אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאִם אֵין לוֹ גַּדְּלֵהוּ מִשֶּׁל אֶחָיו? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהַכֹּהֵן הַגָּדוֹל מֵאֶחָיו אֲשֶׁר יוּצַק עַל רֹאשׁוֹ״ – גַּדְּלֵהוּ מֵאֶחָיו.
human_translation: king as it is written “And he performed one of all the mitzvot of the Lord his God” one who has only the Lord his God upon him. An anointed as it is written: “And the priest that is greatest among his brethren” that he is greater than his brethren in beauty, in power, in wisdom, and in wealth, Others say: From where that if does not have make him great from of his brethren? The verse states: “And the priest that is greatest among his brethren upon whose head the anointing oil is poured” Make him great from of his brethren,
llm_translation: Prince - as it is written: "And he shall do one of all the commandments of the Lord his God." One who has only the Lord his God upon him. Messiah - as it is written: "And the high priest is greater than his brothers," that he is greater than his brothers in beauty, in strength, in wisdom, and in wealth. Others say: From where do we know that if he does not have greatness from his brothers? The Talmud teaches: "And the high priest is greater than his brothers who had the anointing oil poured on his head" - he is greater than his brothers.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבִינָא מֵרַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: נָשִׂיא שֶׁנִּצְטָרַע, מַהוּ? מִידְחָא דְּחֵי, אוֹ מִיפְטָר פְּטִיר? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: דִּילָךְ, אוֹ דְּגַזָּא?
human_translation: Ravina raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak: a king who was afflicted with leprosy what is he eliminated Or exempted, said to your or from treasure [ degazza ]?
llm_translation: Requested of him Ravina from Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: A leader who contracted tzara'at, what is the law? Does he immediately shave or does he become exempt? He said to him: According to your opinion, or according to the decree?

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: מָשִׁיחַ פָּטוּר מִכּוּלָּן. אָמַר רָבָא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא? אָמַר קְרָא: ״זֶה קׇרְבַּן אַהֲרֹן וּבָנָיו״. זוֹ בָּאָה חוֹבָה לוֹ, וְאֵין אַחֶרֶת בָּאָה חוֹבָה לוֹ,
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Akiva says: An anointed is exempt from all Rava said: What is the reason of Rabbi Akiva? the verse states: “This is the offering of Aaron and of his sons this comes an obligation for him, and no other comes an obligation for him.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Akiva says, "The Messiah is exempt from all commandments." Rava said: What is the reason for Rabbi Akiva's statement? He said: It is derived from a verse, "This is the offering of Aaron and his sons." This one offering is obligatory for him, and no other offering is obligatory for him.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: כִּי מְמַעֵט לֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא – מִדַּלֵּי דַלּוּת, וּמַאי נִיהוּ? עֲשִׂירִית הָאֵיפָה. אֲבָל עֲנִיּוּת וַעֲשִׁירוּת, לָא מַעֲטֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא! לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְכִפֶּר עָלָיו הַכֹּהֵן עַל חַטָּאתוֹ אֲשֶׁר חָטָא מֵאַחַת מֵאֵלֶּה״. הַמִּתְכַּפֵּר בְּאַחַת – מִתְכַּפֵּר בְּכוּלָּן, וְשֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּפֵּר בְּאַחַת – אֵין מִתְכַּפֵּר בְּכוּלָּן.
human_translation: But say when the Merciful One excludes from extreme poverty? And what is it? one-tenth of an ephah But the Merciful One did not exclude him poverty wealth. should not enter your mind, as it is written “And the priest shall atone for him for his sin that he has committed from one of these” One who gains atonement with one gains atonement with any of and one who not gain atonement with one not gain atonement with any of
llm_translation: And why? Because the Merciful One is sparing him - from the abundance of sparing. And what is it? A tenth of an ephah. But poverty and wealth, the Merciful One does not spare! Your opinion is not valid, as it is written: "And the priest shall make atonement for him concerning his sin that he sinned from one of these." One who atones with one - atones for all of them, and one who does not atone with one - does not atone for all of them.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהָיָה כִּי יֶאְשַׁם לְאַחַת מֵאֵלֶּה״, הָכִי נָמֵי: דְּכׇל הַמִּתְחַיֵּיב בְּאַחַת – מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּכוּלָּן, וְשֶׁאֵין מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּאַחַת – אֵין מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּכוּלָּן. אַלְּמָה תְּנַן, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: נָשִׂיא חַיָּיב חוּץ מִשְּׁמִיעַת קוֹל!
human_translation: But if that is so, which is written “And it shall be when he shall be guilty of one of these matters” so too Anyone who becomes liable in one can become liable in any of and who does not become liable in one cannot become liable in any of Why, we learn Rabbi Akiva says: king is liable except for hearing of a voice,
llm_translation: Rather, from now on, as it is written: "And when he shall be guilty in one of these," so it is stated: Whoever becomes liable for one is liable for all, and one who is not liable for one is not liable for all. Why do we learn this? Rabbi Akiva says: A prince is liable except for causing a sound to be heard!

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי וְרָבָא דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: ״מֵאַחַת״ מַשְׁמַע לֵיהּ, ״לְאַחַת״ לָא מַשְׁמַע לֵיהּ. וּמַאי שְׁנָא ״מֵאַחַת״ דְּמַשְׁמַע לֵיהּ?
human_translation: Abaye and Rava both say learns “From one” He does not learn “Of one” And what is different “from one” that he learns
llm_translation: Abaye and Rava both say: "From one" implies to him, "to one" does not imply to him. And what is the difference between "from one" that implies to him?

hebrew_text: דְּכַתְבֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא לְבַסּוֹף גַּבֵּי עֲשִׂירִית הָאֵיפָה, לְמֵימְרָא דְּכֹל דְּמִחַיַּיב בַּעֲשִׂירִית הָאֵיפָה – מִחַיַּיב בְּכוּלָּן, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּאַחַת אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּכוּלָּן, נִכְתְּבֵיהּ לְהַאי ״מֵאַחַת מֵאֵלֶּה״ בְּדַלּוּת, אִי נָמֵי בַּעֲשִׁירוּת.
human_translation: that the Merciful One wrote it at the end with regard to the one-tenth of an ephah to say that anyone who can become liable to bring the one-tenth of an ephah can become liable to any of them. As, if it enters your mind one can become liable to one even though he cannot become liable to any of them, let write this From one of these, with regard to poverty, alternatively, with regard to wealth.
llm_translation: The Merciful One wrote in the end regarding a tenth of an ephah, to say that whoever is obligated in a tenth of an ephah - is obligated in all of them, for if it enters your mind that you are obligated in one even though you are not obligated in all of them, it was written for this "from one of these" in exclusivity, or rather in the tenth.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ כׇּל הַמִּצְוֹת שֶׁבְּתוֹרָה שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנָן כָּרֵת וְעַל שִׁגְגָתָן חַטָּאת – הַיָּחִיד מֵבִיא כִּשְׂבָּה וּשְׂעִירָה, וְהַנָּשִׂיא שָׂעִיר, וּמָשִׁיחַ וּבֵית דִּין מְבִיאִין פַּר. וּבַעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה – הַיָּחִיד וְהַנָּשִׂיא וְהַמָּשִׁיחַ מְבִיאִין שְׂעִירָה, וּבֵית דִּין פַּר וְשָׂעִיר; פַּר לְעוֹלָה וְשָׂעִיר לְחַטָּאת.
human_translation: For all mitzvot that are in the Torah for whose intentional liable karet and for whose unwitting a sin-offering, the individual brings a ewe or female goat and the king a male goat and an anointed and a court bring a bull. And for idol worship, the individual, and the king, and the anointed bring a female goat, and the court a bull and a goat: A bull for a burnt-offering and a goat for a sin-offering.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: All the commandments in the Torah that one is liable for intentional violation incur the penalty of excision, and for unintentional violation, the penalty is a sin offering. An individual brings a female goat or a ewe, a leader brings a he-goat, and the anointed priest and the court bring a bull. In matters of idol worship, an individual, a leader, and the anointed priest bring a female goat, and the court brings a bull and a he-goat; a bull for a burnt offering and a he-goat for a sin offering.

hebrew_text: אָשָׁם תָּלוּי – הַיָּחִיד וְהַנָּשִׂיא חַיָּיבִין, וּמָשִׁיחַ וּבֵית דִּין פְּטוּרִין. אָשָׁם וַדַּאי – הַיָּחִיד וְהַנָּשִׂיא וְהַמָּשִׁיחַ חַיָּיבִין, וּבֵית דִּין פְּטוּרִין.
human_translation: a provisional guilt-offering, the individual and the king are liable, and an anointed and a court are exempt. a definite guilt-offering, the individual, the king, and the anointed are liable, and a court is exempt.
llm_translation: Guilt offering suspended - the individual and the leader are obligated, and the anointed one and the court are exempt. Guilt offering definite - the individual and the leader and the anointed one are obligated, and the court is exempt.

hebrew_text: עַל שְׁמִיעַת הַקּוֹל, וְעַל בִּטּוּי שְׂפָתַיִם, וְעַל טוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו – בֵּית דִּין פְּטוּרִין, וְהַיָּחִיד וְהַנָּשִׂיא וְהַמָּשִׁיחַ חַיָּיבִין, אֶלָּא שֶׁאֵין כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל מָשִׁיחַ חַיָּיב עַל טוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן. וּמָה הֵן מְבִיאִין? קׇרְבַּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: הַנָּשִׂיא מֵבִיא שָׂעִיר.
human_translation: For hearing of a voice, and for an utterance of the lips, and for the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial a court is exempt, and the individual, the king, and the anointed are liable. But an anointed High Priest not liable for the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial the statement of Rabbi Shimon. And what they bring? a sliding-scale offering Rabbi Elazar says: The king brings a goat.
llm_translation: Regarding the hearing of the voice, and the expression of the lips, and the impurity of the Sanctuary and its holy items - the court is exempt, but the individual, the prince, and the anointed one are liable, except that the High Priest, the anointed one, is not liable for the impurity of the Sanctuary and its holy items, the words of Rabbi Shimon. And what do they bring? A burnt offering and a sin offering. Rabbi Elazar says: The prince brings a he-goat.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הָיָה נוֹתֵן כְּלָל: כֹּל שֶׁהַיָּחִיד בְּאָשָׁם תָּלוּי – הַנָּשִׂיא כַּיּוֹצֵא בּוֹ, מָשִׁיחַ וּבֵית דִּין פְּטוּרִין. וְכֹל שֶׁהוּא בְּאָשָׁם וַדַּאי – נָשִׂיא וּמָשִׁיחַ כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּהֶן, וּבֵית דִּין פְּטוּרִין.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Shimon would posit a principle: any which the individual to a provisional guilt-offering, the king like and an anointed and a court are exempt. And any which to a definite guilt-offering, a king and an anointed like and court is exempt.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: Rabbi Shimon used to state a general principle: Anyone whose guilt offering is dependent on an individual – the prince is exempt like him, the anointed one (Messiah) and the court are exempt. And anyone whose guilt offering is certain – the prince and the anointed one are like him, and the court is exempt."

hebrew_text: שְׁמִיעַת הַקּוֹל, וּבִטּוּי שְׂפָתַיִם, וְטוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו – בֵּית דִּין פְּטוּרִין, נָשִׂיא וּמָשִׁיחַ חַיָּיבִין, אֶלָּא שֶׁאֵין הַנָּשִׂיא חַיָּיב בִּשְׁמִיעַת הַקּוֹל, וְלֹא מָשִׁיחַ בְּטוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו. כׇּל שֶׁהוּא בְּעוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד – נָשִׂיא כַּיּוֹצֵא בּוֹ, מָשִׁיחַ וּבֵית דִּין פְּטוּרִין.
human_translation: hearing of a voice, and an utterance of the lips, and the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial a court is exempt, and a king and an anointed are liable. But the king is not liable in hearing of a voice, and an anointed for the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial any which to a sliding-scale a king is like and an anointed and a court are exempt.
llm_translation: The hearing of the voice, and the expression of the lips, and the impurity of the sanctuary and its holy things - the court is exempt, the prince and the anointed one are liable, except that the prince is not liable for the hearing of the voice, and the anointed one is not liable for the impurity of the sanctuary and its holy things. Anyone who ascends and descends - the prince is like him, the anointed one and the court are exempt.

hebrew_text: הָא גּוּפַהּ קַשְׁיָא, אָמְרַתְּ: שֶׁאֵין מָשִׁיחַ חַיָּיב בְּטוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו, בְּטוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו – הוּא דְּפָטוּר, אֲבָל בִּשְׁמִיעַת הַקּוֹל וּבִטּוּי שְׂפָתַיִם – חַיָּיב. אֵימָא סֵיפָא: כֹּל שֶׁהוּא בְּעוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד – נָשִׂיא כַּיּוֹצֵא בּוֹ, מָשִׁיחַ וּבֵית דִּין פְּטוּרִין, קָתָנֵי: מָשִׁיחַ וּבֵית דִּין פְּטוּרִין, מָה בֵּית דִּין פְּטוּרִין מִכּוּלְּהוֹן – אַף מָשִׁיחַ פָּטוּר מִכּוּלְּהוֹן.
human_translation: This itself difficult. You said that an anointed not liable for the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial It is for the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial that he is exempt, but liable for hearing of a voice and a statement of the lips. Say the latter clause any which to a sliding-scale a king like and an anointed and a court are exempt. He teaches: An anointed priest and a court are exempt; just as a court is exempt from all of so too, an anointed priest is exempt from all of them,
llm_translation: The body of the text is difficult, you said: "The Messiah is not obligated in the impurity of the Temple and its sanctities, in the impurity of the Temple and its sanctities - he is exempt, but in hearing the voice and the movement of the lips - he is obligated." Let us say the conclusion: "Anyone who is ascending and descending - a leader like him, the Messiah and the court are exempt." The Mishnah teaches: "The Messiah and the court are exempt, just as the court is exempt from all of them - so too the Messiah is exempt from all of them."

hebrew_text: קַשְׁיָין אַהֲדָדֵי!
human_translation: difficult, one another.
llm_translation: Difficult are the words of Ahadadei!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: לָא קַשְׁיָא. כָּאן – בְּדַלּוּת, כָּאן – בְּדַלֵּי דַלּוּת. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בַּחֲדָא וּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא: סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בְּדַלֵּי דַלּוּת דְּפָטוּר, וּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ בְּדַלּוּת.
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: not difficult, Here, in poverty, there, in extreme poverty. And Rabbi Shimon holds in accordance with Rabbi Akiva with regard to one and disagrees with him with regard to one He holds in accordance with Rabbi Akiva in extreme poverty that exempt And he disagrees with in poverty,
llm_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: It is not difficult. Here - in the case of abundance, here - in the case of the abundance of abundance. And Rabbi Shimon thought of it like Rabbi Akiva in one aspect, and disagreed with him in one aspect: he thought of it like Rabbi Akiva in the abundance of abundance that one is exempt, and he disagreed with him in the abundance of abundance.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא שֶׁאֵין כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל חַיָּיב כּוּ׳. אָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן? דִּכְתִיב: ״וְנִכְרְתָה הַנֶּפֶשׁ הַהִיא מִתּוֹךְ הַקָּהָל״, מִי שֶׁקׇּרְבָּנוֹ שָׁוֶה לַקָּהָל. יָצָא זֶה שֶׁאֵין קׇרְבָּנוֹ שָׁוֶה לַקָּהָל.
human_translation: But High Priest is not liable Ḥizkiyya said: What is the reason of Rabbi Shimon? as it is written that soul shall be excised [ venikhreta ] from the midst of the congregation, one whose offering equals of the congregation, exclude as his offering does not equal of the congregation,
llm_translation: Rather, the High Priest is not liable. Chizkiyah said: What is the reason for Rabbi Shimon's opinion? For it is written: "And that soul shall be cut off from among the congregation," indicating that one whose offering is not equal to the congregation. This excludes one whose offering is not equal to the congregation.

hebrew_text: אִם כֵּן, נָשִׂיא נָמֵי – אֵין קׇרְבָּנוֹ שָׁוֶה לַקָּהָל! שָׁוֶה בְּכַפָּרָה דְּיוֹם הַכִּיפּוּרִים. אִם כֵּן, כֹּהֲנִים נָמֵי לֹא שָׁווּ לַקָּהָל בְּכַפָּרָה דְּיוֹם הַכִּיפּוּרִים! כֹּהֲנִים שָׁווּ לַקָּהָל בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת דְּשָׁנָה כּוּלָּהּ.
human_translation: If so, a king too, his offering does not equal of the congregation, equals in the atonement of Yom Kippur, If so, priests too do not equal the congregation in the atonement of Yom Kippur, Priests equal the congregation with regard to the rest of the mitzvot of the entire year.
llm_translation: If so, a blemished prince - his offering is not equal to the congregation! It is equal in atonement on the Day of Atonement. If so, blemished priests are not equal to the congregation in atonement on the Day of Atonement! Priests are equal to the congregation in all other commandments that are entirely different.

hebrew_text: מָשִׁיחַ נָמֵי, הָא שָׁוֶה בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת דְּשָׁנָה! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא, אֵימָא הָכִי: מִי שֶׁחַטָּאתוֹ שָׁוָה לִיחִידִים, וּמַאי נִיהוּ קָהָל.
human_translation: anointed priest, too, equals with regard to the rest of the mitzvot of the year. Rather, Rava said: Say this: One whose sin-offering equals individuals. And who are congregation.
llm_translation: Messiah is dead, the one who is equal in other commandments is different! Rather Rava said, say thus: One whose sin is equal to individuals, and what is the difference with the congregation.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: הַנָּשִׂיא מֵבִיא שָׂעִיר וְכוּ׳. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אֶלָּא בְּטוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו, הוֹאִיל וְנֶאֱמַר כָּרֵת בּוֹ כְּבִקְבוּעָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: The king brings a goat, Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Eliezer stated only with regard to the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial since karet is stated concerning it, as in a fixed
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: "The prince brings a he-goat, etc." Rabbi Yochanan said: Rabbi Eliezer only said this regarding impurity of the sanctuary and its holy items, since it is stated, "He shall be cut off from among his people" in a definitive manner.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר עַל כּוּלְּהוֹן קָאָמַר, מִכְּדִי שְׂעִיר נָשִׂיא וּפַר מָשִׁיחַ בִּמְקוֹם יָחִיד לְחַטָּאת קָאֵי. נִיתְנֵי נָמֵי: מָשִׁיחַ מֵבִיא פַּר בִּשְׁמִיעַת קוֹל וּבִטּוּי שְׂפָתַיִם. אֶלָּא מִדְּלָא קָתָנֵי מָשִׁיחַ, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ אַטּוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו קָאֵי, דְּמָשִׁיחַ פָּטוּר.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: So too, it is reasonable, as if it enters your mind Rabbi Eliezer says for all since the goat of a king and the bull of an anointed stand in place of an individual to a sin-offering, let also teach: An anointed brings a bull for hearing of a voice and an utterance of the lips. Rather, from that does not teach an anointed learn from it stands to the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial which an anointed exempt,
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: So it appears reasonable, for if it were to enter your mind, Rabbi Eliezer is speaking about all of them, since the goat of the leader and the bull of the anointed high priest for a sin offering stand in place of an individual. It should be said: The anointed high priest brings a bull with the utterance of his voice and the movement of his lips. Rather, since the anointed high priest is not mentioned, infer from it that the atonement of the sanctuary and its holy items stands, for the anointed high priest is exempt.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב נָתָן לְרַב פָּפָּא: מִמַּאי? דִּלְמָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אַכּוּלְּהוֹן קָאֵי, וּבְמָשִׁיחַ סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, דְּאָמַר: מָשִׁיחַ פָּטוּר בְּכוּלָּן! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מִי פָּטַר לֵיהּ מִפַּר? וְתוּ לָא מִידִּי.
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa: From where Perhaps Rabbi Eliezer stands to all of them. And with regard to an anointed he holds in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, who says: An anointed is exempt from all of said to him: And Rabbi Akiva, does he exempt from a bull? And nothing more
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Huna son of Rav Natan said to Rav Papa: From where? Perhaps Rabbi Eliezer is supporting them, and regarding the Messiah, he holds like Rabbi Akiva, who said: The Messiah exempts them all! He said to him: And did Rabbi Akiva exempt him from the cow? But it is not so.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא אָשָׁם. תָּנֵי תַּנָּא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב שֵׁשֶׁת: אָשָׁם תָּלוּי בָּא עַל טוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: דַּאֲמַר לָךְ מַנִּי? רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הִיא, דְּאָמַר: הוֹאִיל וְנֶאֱמַר בּוֹ כָּרֵת כְּבִקְבוּעָה, מַיְיתֵי נָשִׂיא שָׂעִיר עָלֶיהָ. וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא אָשָׁם תָּלוּי! קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabbi Eliezer concedes that does not bring a guilt-offering The tanna recited before Rav Sheshet: a provisional guilt-offering comes for the defiling of Temple or its sacrificial said to him: Who said to you? Is it Rabbi Eliezer, who said: Since karet is stated in its as in a fixed a king brings a goat for But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Rabbi Eliezer concedes that does not bring guilt-offering? difficult.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Rabbi Eliezer admits that one does not bring an Asham. A Tanna taught before Rav Sheshet: The Asham is dependent upon coming into contact with impurity of the sanctuary and its holy items. He said to him: Did Rabbi Eliezer say this to you? It is he who said: Since it is stated regarding it the Asham as a certainty of being cut off, let the leader bring a he-goat offering upon it. And Rabbi Yochanan said: Rabbi Eliezer admits that one does not bring a dependent Asham! This is a contradiction.

hebrew_text: הֲדַרַן עֲלָיךְ הוֹרָה כֹּהֵן מָשִׁיחַ
llm_translation: We will return to you, O Teacher, Kohen Mashiah.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ כֹּהֵן מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁחָטָא וְאַחַר כָּךְ עָבַר מִמְּשִׁיחוּתוֹ, וְכֵן נָשִׂיא שֶׁחָטָא וְאַחַר כָּךְ עָבַר מִגְּדוּלָּתוֹ – כֹּהֵן מָשִׁיחַ מֵבִיא פַּר, וְהַנָּשִׂיא מֵבִיא שָׂעִיר. מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁעָבַר מִמְּשִׁיחוּתוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ חָטָא, וְכֵן הַנָּשִׂיא שֶׁעָבַר מִגְּדוּלָּתוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ חָטָא – כֹּהֵן מָשִׁיחַ מֵבִיא פַּר, וְהַנָּשִׂיא כְּהֶדְיוֹט.
human_translation: an anointed priest who sinned and thereafter moved on from his anointment, and likewise a king [ nasi ] who sinned and thereafter moved on from his prominence an anointed priest brings a bull and the king brings a goat, an anointed who moved on from his anointment and thereafter sinned, and likewise the king who moved on from his prominence and thereafter sinned, an anointed priest brings a bull, and the king like a commoner [ kehedyot ].
llm_translation: It was taught: If the anointed priest sinned and then transgressed from his anointing, and similarly, if the prince sinned and then transgressed from his greatness - the anointed priest brings a bull, and the prince brings a he-goat. If the anointed priest transgressed from his anointing and then sinned, and similarly, if the prince transgressed from his greatness and then sinned - the anointed priest brings a bull, and the prince brings like an ordinary person.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הַשְׁתָּא יֵשׁ לוֹמַר: עָבַר מִמְּשִׁיחוּתוֹ,
human_translation: Now it can be said: who moved on from his anointment
llm_translation: Gemara: Now, at this time, it is possible to say: He has passed from his anointing.

hebrew_text: וְאַחַר כָּךְ חָטָא מֵבִיא פַּר, חָטָא וְאַחַר כָּךְ עָבַר מִמְּשִׁיחוּתוֹ צְרִיכָא לְמֵימַר? מִשּׁוּם דְּקָתָנֵי גַּבֵּי נָשִׂיא, דְּכִי עָבַר מִנְּשִׂיאוּתוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ חָטָא – כְּהֶדְיוֹט מַיְיתֵי, אַהָכִי תָּנֵי גַּבֵּי מָשִׁיחַ [חָטָא וְאַחַר כָּךְ עָבַר] מֵבִיא פַּר.
human_translation: and thereafter sinned brings a bull. sinned and thereafter moved on from his anointment need to be said? Due to that teaches with regard to a king, that when he moved on from his sovereignty and thereafter sinned he brings. like a commoner; therefore, he teaches with regard to an anointed he sinned and thereafter moved on he brings a bull.
llm_translation: And after that he sinned, he brings a bull, if he sinned and then transgressed from his anointing, is it necessary to say? Because it was taught regarding a prince, that when he transgressed from his princely status and then sinned - like a commoner he brings, so too it was taught regarding the anointed one if he sinned and then transgressed he brings a bull.

hebrew_text: מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״וְהִקְרִיב עַל חַטָּאתוֹ״, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁמֵּבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר,
human_translation: From where are these matters as the Sages taught: “And he shall sacrifice for his sin [ ḥattato ] teaches that he brings his sin-offering [ ḥattato ] after he has moved on
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "What are these words?" For the Rabbis taught: "And he shall bring for his sin offering," teaches that one brings his sin offering from the past,

hebrew_text: שֶׁיָּכוֹל, וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: וּמָה נָשִׂיא שֶׁמֵּבִיא בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה – אֵין מֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר, מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה – [לֹא] כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן! תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהִקְרִיב עַל חַטָּאתוֹ״, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁמֵּבִיא עַל חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר.
human_translation: might Could this not inference? And if a king, who brings for the unwitting of an action, does not bring his sin-offering from that he has moved on an anointed who does not bring for the unwitting of an action rather, only for absence of the matter with unwitting of an action, not all the more so the verse states: “And he shall sacrifice for his sin [ ḥattato ] teaches that he brings his sin-offering [ ḥattato ] after he has moved on
llm_translation: The text: "That he is able, and is it not so: And what about a prince who brings a sin offering for an unwitting transgression - he does not bring his sin offering for a past act, the anointed one who does not bring a sin offering for an unwitting transgression except for a concealed matter with an unwitting transgression - certainly not! The Talmud teaches: 'And he shall offer for his sin,' teaches that he brings his sin offering for a past act."

hebrew_text: וְנַיְיתֵי נָמֵי נָשִׂיא מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה – מֵבִיא חַטָּאת מִשֶּׁעָבַר, נָשִׂיא שֶׁמֵּבִיא חַטָּאת בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁמֵּבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר! תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר נָשִׂיא יֶחֱטָא״, כְּשֶׁהוּא נָשִׂיא – אִין, כְּשֶׁהוּא הֶדְיוֹט – לָא.
human_translation: And let a king too, bring based on an a fortiori And if an anointed who does not bring for the unwitting of an action, brings a sin-offering after he has moved on a king, who brings a sin-offering for the unwitting of an action, is it not logical that he brings his sin-offering once he has moved on the verse states: “When a king sins” when he is king, yes, when he is a commoner, no,
llm_translation: And it was taught in the name of the Prince with an a fortiori argument: Just as the anointed one who does not bring a sin-offering for an unwitting transgression - brings a sin-offering for a past sin, a Prince who brings a sin-offering for an unwitting transgression - it is not the law that he brings his sin-offering for a past sin! The Talmud teaches: "When a Prince sins," when he is a Prince - yes, when he is a commoner - no.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ חָטְאוּ עַד שֶׁלֹּא נִתְמַנּוּ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִתְמַנּוּ – הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ כְּהֶדְיוֹטוֹת. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אִם נוֹדַע לָהֶם עַד שֶׁלֹּא נִתְמַנּוּ – חַיָּיבִים, וּמִשֶּׁנִּתְמַנּוּ – פְּטוּרִים.
human_translation: sinned before they were appointed, and thereafter they were appointed, these like commoners; Rabbi Shimon says: If it became known to them, before they were appointed they are liable but after they were appointed they are exempt.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: They sinned before they were appointed, and after they were appointed - these are like laymen. Rabbi Shimon says: If it was known to them before they were appointed - they are liable, but once they were appointed - they are exempt.

hebrew_text: אֵיזֶהוּ נָשִׂיא? זֶה מֶלֶךְ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מִכׇּל מִצְוֹת ה׳ אֱלֹהָיו״, שֶׁאֵין עַל גַּבָּיו אֶלָּא ה׳ אֱלֹהָיו.
human_translation: Who is nasi ? This is a king, as it is stated: of all the mitzvot of the Lord his God who has only the Lord his God over him
llm_translation: Which is a prince? This is a king, as it is said: "Of all the commandments of the Lord his God," indicating that there is nothing upon him except the Lord his God.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אִם הַכֹּהֵן הַמָּשִׁיחַ יֶחֱטָא (לְאַשְׁמַת)״ – פְּרָט לַקּוֹדְמוֹת,
human_translation: From where are these matters as the Sages taught “If the anointed priest shall sin to bring guilt” exclude the prior
llm_translation: Gemara: What are these words teaching us? For the Rabbis taught: "If the anointed priest sins (bringing guilt)..." - this excludes previous cases.

hebrew_text: שֶׁיָּכוֹל, וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: וּמָה נָשִׂיא שֶׁמֵּבִיא בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה – אֵין מֵבִיא עַל הַקּוֹדְמוֹת, מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא אֶלָּא עַל הֶעְלֵם דָּבָר עִם שִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא יָבִיא עַל הַקּוֹדְמוֹת!
human_translation: As might Could this not inference? And if a king, who brings for the unwitting of an action, does not bring for the prior an anointed who brings only for absence of the matter with the unwitting of an action, is it not logical that he will not bring for the prior
llm_translation: The one who is able, and isn't this the law: And what about a leader who brings an unintentional sin offering - he does not bring it for previous offenses, the anointed one who only brings for a hidden matter with an unintentional sin offering - it is not the law that he should bring it for previous offenses!

hebrew_text: לֹא, אִם אָמַרְתָּ בְּנָשִׂיא – שֶׁכֵּן אֵין מֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר, תֹּאמַר בְּמָשִׁיחַ – שֶׁמֵּבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר, הוֹאִיל וּמֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר – יָבִיא עַל הַקּוֹדְמוֹת? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״הַמָּשִׁיחַ יֶחֱטָא״, חָטָא כְּשֶׁהוּא מָשִׁיחַ – מֵבִיא, כְּשֶׁהוּא הֶדְיוֹט – אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא.
human_translation: No, if you said with regard to a king, as he does not bring his sin-offering once he has moved on Shall you say with regard to an anointed who brings his sin-offering once he has moved on Since he brings his sin-offering once he has moved on he shall bring for the prior the verse states: the anointed priest shall sin,” he sins when he is an anointed priest he brings when he is an ordinary he does not bring
llm_translation: Not, if you say in a prince - that so he does not bring his sin offering from the past, you would say in the Messiah - that he brings his sin offering from the past, since he brings his sin offering from the past - should he bring for the previous ones? The Talmud teaches: "The anointed one shall sin," if he is the anointed one - he brings, if he is a commoner - he does not bring.

hebrew_text: וְתַנְיָא נָמֵי גַּבֵּי נָשִׂיא כְּהַאי גַּוְונָא: ״אֲשֶׁר נָשִׂיא יֶחֱטָא״ – פְּרָט לַקּוֹדְמוֹת,
human_translation: And it is also taught in this way with regard to a king: “When a king sins” exclude the prior
llm_translation: "And it was taught in a Baraita in the name of Rabban Gamliel the Elder in such a manner: 'When a leader sins' - this excludes the earlier leaders."

hebrew_text: שֶׁיָּכוֹל וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: וּמָה מָשִׁיחַ שֶׁמֵּבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר – אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא עַל הַקּוֹדְמוֹת, נָשִׂיא שֶׁאֵין מֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ מִשֶּׁעָבַר – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא יָבִיא עַל הַקּוֹדְמוֹת?
human_translation: As might Could this not inference? If an anointed who brings his sin-offering once he has moved on does not bring for the prior a king, who does not bring his sin-offering once he has moved on is it not logical that he will not bring for the prior
llm_translation: The text reads: "That he is able, and is it not the law: And what about the anointed one who brings his sin offering from the past - he does not bring for the previous sins, a prince who does not bring his sin offering from the past - is it not the law that he should not bring for the previous sins?"

hebrew_text: מָה לְמָשִׁיחַ שֶׁכֵּן אֵין מֵבִיא בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה, תֹּאמַר בְּנָשִׂיא שֶׁמֵּבִיא בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה? הוֹאִיל וּמֵבִיא בְּשִׁגְגַת מַעֲשֶׂה – יָבִיא עַל הַקּוֹדְמוֹת? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר נָשִׂיא יֶחֱטָא״ – שֶׁחָטָא וַהֲרֵי הוּא נָשִׂיא, וְלֹא שֶׁחָטָא וְעוֹדֵהוּ הֶדְיוֹט.
human_translation: What about an anointed in that he does not bring for the unwitting of an action Shall you say with regard to a king, who brings for the unwitting of an action Since he brings for the unwitting of an action shall he bring for the prior the verse states: “When a king sins,” where he sins and he is king, and not where he sins and he is still a commoner.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: What about the anointed one, that he does not bring a sin-offering for an unwitting transgression? You would say about a prince who brings a sin-offering for an unwitting transgression? Since he brings a sin-offering for an unwitting transgression – should he bring it for previous ones? The verse teaches: "When a prince sins" – that he sinned and yet he is a prince, not that he sinned and he is still a commoner.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אֲשֶׁר נָשִׂיא יֶחֱטָא״, יָכוֹל גְּזֵרָה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אִם הַכֹּהֵן הַמָּשִׁיחַ יֶחֱטָא״, מָה לְהַלָּן לִכְשֶׁיֶּחֱטָא – אַף כָּאן לִכְשֶׁיֶּחֱטָא.
human_translation: the Sages taught: “When [ asher ] a king sins.” might a decree, the verse states: “If the anointed priest shall sin” Just as there In the event that shall sin, so too here, In the event that shall sin.
llm_translation: The sages taught: "If the anointed priest sins," could it be a decree? The Talmud teaches us: "If the anointed priest sins," just as there when he sins - so too here when he sins.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: יָכוֹל גְּזֵרָה, גְּזֵרָה מֵהֵיכָא תֵּיתֵי?
human_translation: The Master said: might a decree. A decree? From where would this be derived?
llm_translation: Said Mar: Can a decree, a decree, from where does it come?

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי אִין, אַשְׁכְּחַן, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְנָתַתִּי נֶגַע צָרַעַת בְּבֵית אֶרֶץ אֲחֻזַּתְכֶם״, בְּשׂוֹרָה הִיא לָהֶם שֶׁנְּגָעִים בָּאִים עֲלֵיהֶם, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: פְּרָט לְנִגְעֵי אוֹנָסִין. לָאו אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּשׂוֹרָה? הָכָא נָמֵי אֵימָא גְּזֵרָה הִיא! הִלְכָּךְ כְּתִיב: ״אִם״.
human_translation: say: Yes, we find as it is written: and I shall place the mark of leprosy in a house of the land of your possession” These are tidings them, that leprous marks come upon them the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says: to the exclusion of leprosy circumstances beyond one’s control, Didn’t Rabbi Yehuda say tidings, Here too, say it is a decree Therefore, it is written: “If
llm_translation: They said: We find, as it is written: "And I will put a plague of leprosy upon a house in the land of your possession," it is a warning to them that plagues will come upon them, the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says: This excludes cases of forced plagues. Did Rabbi Yehuda not say this in the Torah? Here too, let us say it is a decree! Therefore it is written: "If."

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, נִגְעֵי אוֹנָסִין מִי לָא מְטַמּוּ? וְהָא תַּנְיָא: ״אָדָם כִּי יִהְיֶה״ – מִן הַדִּבּוּר וְאֵילָךְ. וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: טָמֵא בְּזָב וְטָמֵא בִּנְגָעִים, מָה זָב – מִן הַדִּבּוּר וְאֵילָךְ, אַף נְגָעִים – מִן הַדִּבּוּר וְאֵילָךְ?
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Shimon, do marks circumstances beyond one’s control not cause ritual impurity? But isn’t it taught “When a person shall have from statement onward, And could this not logical inference: deemed impure in a zav , and deemed impure in marks. Just as a zav from the statement onward, so too, marks, from that statement onward.
llm_translation: To Rabbi Shimon, who is responsible for accidental injuries? But isn't it taught: "When a man shall have" - from the statement and onwards. Isn't this a logical conclusion: One who is impure due to a seminal emission and one who is impure due to skin afflictions, just as a seminal emission - from the statement and onwards, so too skin afflictions - from the statement and onwards?

hebrew_text: לֹא, אִם אָמַרְתָּ בְּזָב שֶׁכֵּן אֵין מְטַמֵּא בְּאוֹנֶס, תֹּאמַר בִּנְגָעִים שֶׁמְּטַמְּאִין בְּאוֹנֶס? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אָדָם כִּי יִהְיֶה״, מִן הַדִּבּוּר וְאֵילָךְ. רָבָא אָמַר: פְּרָט לְנִגְעֵי רוּחוֹת. רַב פָּפָּא אָמַר: פְּרָט לְנִגְעֵי כְשָׁפִים.
human_translation: No, if you said with regard to a zav , as he does not become impure by circumstances beyond his control. Shall you say with regard to marks, which impart ritual impurity by circumstances beyond one’s control? the verse states: “When a person shall have,” from statement onward. Rava says to exclude marks by spirits. Rav Pappa says to exclude marks by sorcery.
llm_translation: Not if you say regarding a seminal emission that indeed it does not render impure due to coercion, will you say regarding skin diseases that do render impure due to coercion? The Torah teaches: "When a man shall have" - from the wording and onwards. Rava said: This is excluding the impurity of spirits. Rav Papa said: This is excluding the impurity of witchcraft.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אֲשֶׁר נָשִׂיא יֶחֱטָא״ – פְּרָט לְחוֹלֶה. מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה לֵיהּ חוֹלֶה, אִידְּחִי לֵיהּ מִנְּשִׂיאוּתֵיהּ? אָמַר רַב אַבְדִּימִי בַּר חָמָא: פְּרָט לְנָשִׂיא שֶׁנִּצְטָרַע, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְנַגַּע ה׳ אֶת הַמֶּלֶךְ וַיְהִי מְצֹרָע עַד יוֹם מֹתוֹ וַיֵּשֶׁב בְּבֵית הַחׇפְשִׁית וְיוֹתָם בֶּן הַמֶּלֶךְ עַל הַבַּיִת״. מִדְּקָאָמַר ״בְּבֵית הַחׇפְשִׁית״, מִכְּלָל דְּעַד הַשְׁתָּא עֶבֶד הֲוָה.
human_translation: the Sages taught “When a king sins” to exclude ill. Due to that he is ill, is he removed from his sovereignty? Rav Avdimi bar Ḥama said: to exclude a king who is afflicted with leprosy, as it is stated “And the Lord afflicted the king, so that he was a leper until the day of his death, and dwelt in an independent house. And Jotham, son of the king, was over the household, From that states: “In an independent house,” by inference that until now he was a servant,
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "When a leader sins" - this excludes one who is ill. Because if he were ill, would he be exempt from his leadership? Rav Avdimi bar Hama said: This excludes a leader who contracted tzara'at, as it is stated: "And the Lord afflicted the king with tzara'at until the day of his death, and he dwelt in a separate house, while Yotham, the king's son, was over the house." From the fact that it says "in a separate house," it can be inferred that until then he was a servant.
